Award.AwardTitle: Designing Efficient Platinum-Free Electrocatalysts for Oxygen Reduction Reaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1132777
Linic

The proposal represents a serious attempt at developing an approach to surmounting the most serious problem with low temperature H2 fuel cells. The slow kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction at the cathode significantly reduces the efficiency obtained. To alleviate this, platinum electrocatalysts have been used. Although the negatives of high over-potential and Pt expense are inherent, platinum is one of the few metals stable in the high acid environment conventionally used. The acid-compatible polymer membranes needed for the fuel cell device were developed, so PEM fuel cells represent state-of-art devices, but with significant drawbacks.

PI Suljo Linic from the Chemical Engineering Department at the University of Michigan offers a possible way around these issues. There have been adequate improvements in hydroxide membrane technology which opens the basic as opposed to acidic operating environment to consideration. Many more metals are stable in basic media, so the cost factor or even presence of Pt may be open to review. As a basis, Linic has done some preliminary experiments and computations on various metal surfaces in basic operating media, and postulates some differences in rate limiting steps which govern over-potentials on the various metal surfaces. He hypothesizes that specific Ag surfaces or Ag overlayer surfaces may help alleviate the over-potential issue in addition to replacing expensive Pt. He proposes some specific surface experiments and computational complements to investigate the validity of the hypotheses. Positive results may lead to a revitalization of H2 fuel cells and the use of H2 in certain fuel situations, which represents large technical impact potential.

The broader educational and outreach components were a mixture of traditional and new approaches as proposed by Linic. The PI proposes to use social delivery media vehicles, such as YouTube, as a means of outreach to the high school and college audience. This approach builds on similar successful scientific outreach programs. One may argue with the likelihood, but it is basically another experiment that will be a part of the project. The students at the University who become involved in this project will definitely benefit from constructive integration of nanoscience and electro-catalysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The largest source of the efficiency loss in low temperature H2 fuel cells is the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode. Overcoming the ORR barrier has historically required expensive platinum electro-catalyst which itself suffers an over-potential loss of ~ 300 meV (~ 25 % of the maximum energy supplied by the reaction). Another important reason for the historical focus on the Pt-based electro-catalysts has been the inherent lack of stability of almost every other metal in acid environments where these reactions are conventionally performed. We note that the research has mainly focused on acid environments since proton exchange membranes (PEMs), such as the Nafion ionomer, are comparatively more developed and robust than their hydroxide-conducting counterparts which could be used in a basic environment. Recent advances in hydroxide membrane technology have led to resurgence in alkaline electrolyte cells, and these devices are poised to become a competitive alternative.  The most important advantage of basic operating environments is that the number of metals that are stable in base in significantly larger than those stable in acid, i.e., the space of viable candidate electro-catalysts is significantly expanded in base. For example, while silver is not electrochemically stable under ORR conditions in acid, it is stable in base. This proposal explores alternatives to expensive Pt electro-catalysts for the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction. We have focus on two families of materials: (i) Pt-free electro-catalysts that are active and stable in base, and (ii) Pt-containing alloy materials that can perform the reaction superior compared to pure Pt in acid and base. 

We have utilized quantum chemical Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations to study the mechanism of ORR on the Pt(111), Ag(111) and Au(111) surfaces. The main conclusions of these studies were that: (i) the rate of the ORR reaction on the Pt(111) surface is to a large degree governed by the availability of free Pt sites. Most of these sites are occupied by OH adsorbed on Pt and stabilized by the network of neighboring water molecules, (ii) the rate limiting step responsible for the over-potential loss on Ag and Au surface is the proton-assisted dissociation of O2. We have confirmed experimentally these mechanistic findings in our studies of the kinetics of ORR in these metal surface.

Finally, we have used these mechanistic insights to identify a number of Pt- and Ag-alloys that are promising alternatives to expensive Pt electro-catalysts. Some of these materials have been tested and have been demonstrated to exhibit superior activities compared to the current state-of-the-art.

Broader Impact: The central educations theme of our efforts was to expose undergraduate and high school students as well as the general public to the field of heterogeneous electro-catalysis. We have developed a number of outreach activities including reaching out to high school and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups. For example, we have two weekends when undergraduate students from underrepresented groups visit the University of Michigan. We have used these opportunities to show our laboratory to the students and to explain to them, in a short lecture, what we do and how this impacts the society. We have also had two graduate students from my research group visit a local high school during their science fair. They performed some simple experiments demonstrating the process of the conversions of chemical energy into electrical energy. They also served as judges for the science competition.
